name_origin.etymology: The word derives from the Berber (Amazigh) language, specifically the word 'seksu' or 'kesksu'. It entered North African Arabic as 'kuskusi' and later French/English as 'couscous'. While some theories suggest an onomatopoeic origin (the sound of the steam or the sieve), the linguistic consensus points to the Berber root S-K-S, referring to the action of rolling or rounding the wheat granules.
name_origin.sources_notes: Culinary historians (including Charles Perry and Clifford Wright) confirm the Berber origin, predating the Arab invasion of the Maghreb. The 13th-century Andalusian cookbook 'Fadalat al-Khiwan' confirms its established presence in the region. In Tunisian Judeo-Arabic, it is pronounced 'Kuskusi'.

alternative_names.name: Kuskusi
alternative_names.notes: The standard pronunciation in Tunisia and Libya (كسكسي).

alternative_names.name: Ta'am
alternative_names.notes: Literally means 'food' or 'sustenance'; used in Algeria and Morocco to denote couscous as the staple meal.

similar_dishes.name: Moghrabieh (Maftoul)
similar_dishes.key_difference: Grains are much larger (pearl size) and often coated with flour rather than pure semolina.

similar_dishes.name: Berkoukes (Aich)
similar_dishes.key_difference: Grains are significantly larger than couscous and usually cooked in a soup/sauce rather than steamed over broth.

similar_dishes.name: Fregola Sarda
similar_dishes.key_difference: Toasted in an oven (giving a nutty flavor) and boiled like pasta rather than steamed.

similar_dishes.name: Dambou
similar_dishes.key_difference: Made from rice flour, millet, or corn rather than wheat semolina; often mixed with moringa.
